questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'She runs more faster than her brother in the track events.'
questions.Explanation: 'Faster' is the correct comparative form; 'more faster' is redundant.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice: 'A state-of-the-art software program is being designed by our team to enhance the efficiency of our business operations.'
questions.OptionA: Our team has designed a state-of-the-art software program to enhance the efficiency of our business operations.
questions.OptionB: Our team will be designing a state-of-the-art software program to enhance the efficiency of our business operations.
questions.OptionC: Our team has been designing a state-of-the-art software program to enhance the efficiency of our business operations.
questions.OptionD: Our team is designing a state-of-the-art software program to enhance the efficiency of our business operations.
questions.Explanation: 'Is designing' matches the present continuous tense of the original.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'A questionnaire will distributing to all the participants at the end of the session.'
questions.Explanation: 'Will be distributed' corrects the passive voice structure.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'He asked the speaker some questions until the session.'
questions.Explanation: 'During' is appropriate for an action occurring within a time period.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: '"Don’t forget to bring your umbrella," he said to her.'
questions.OptionA: He told her to bring your umbrella.
questions.OptionB: He told her don’t forget to bring her umbrella.
questions.OptionC: He reminded her to bring her umbrella.
questions.OptionD: He reminded her not to forget to bring your umbrella.
questions.Explanation: 'Reminded' and 'her' adjust the command appropriately.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech: 'Avika says, "I have completed the math assignment."'
questions.OptionA: Avika said that she has completed the math assignment.
questions.OptionB: Avika says that she has completed the math assignment.
questions.OptionC: Avika says that she had completed the math assignment.
questions.OptionD: Avika says that I have completed the math assignment.
questions.Explanation: 'Says' and 'has completed' retain present tense as the statement is current.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech: 'Mother said to Amayra, "Did you finish your homework?"'
questions.OptionA: Mother asked Amayra if she had finished her homework.
questions.OptionB: Mother asked Amayra if she has finished her homework.
questions.OptionC: Mother asked Amayra have you finished your homework.
questions.OptionD: Mother asked Amayra did you finished your homework.
questions.Explanation: 'Had finished' shifts the past tense question correctly.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: '"The sun is shining brightly today," he said, looking out of the window.'
questions.OptionA: Looking out of the window, he said that the sun was shining brightly that day.
questions.OptionB: Looking out of the window, he says that the sun is shining brightly that day.
questions.OptionC: Looking out of the window, he said that the sun was shining brightly today.
questions.OptionD: Looking out of the window, he said that the sun is shining brightly today.
questions.Explanation: 'Was' and 'that day' adjust tense and time in indirect speech.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: 'Manya said that she didn’t want any breakfast.'
questions.OptionA: Manya says, 'She doesn’t want any breakfast.'
questions.OptionB: Manya said, 'I don’t want any breakfast.'
questions.OptionC: Manya said, 'You didn’t want any breakfast.'
questions.OptionD: Manya said, 'She didn’t want any breakfast.'
questions.Explanation: 'I don’t want' restores the original direct statement.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: 'The chef prepared a delicious meal for the guests.'
questions.OptionA: A delicious meal was prepared for the guests by the chef.
questions.OptionB: A delicious meal is prepared for the guests by the chef.
questions.OptionC: A delicious meal was being prepared for the guests by the chef.
questions.OptionD: A delicious meal was preparing for the guests by the chef.
questions.Explanation: 'Was prepared' matches the past tense of the original.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: 'The mechanic did not fix the car yesterday.'
questions.OptionA: The car did not fix by the mechanic yesterday.
questions.OptionB: The car was not fixed by the mechanic yesterday.
questions.OptionC: The mechanic was not fixed by the car yesterday.
questions.OptionD: The car had not been fixed by the mechanic yesterday.
questions.Explanation: 'Was not fixed' correctly negates the past action.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: 'The company will launch a new product next month.'
questions.OptionA: A new product will be launched by the company next month.
questions.OptionB: A new product is to be launched by the company next month.
questions.OptionC: A new company will be launched by the product next month.
questions.OptionD: A new product should be launched by the company next month.
questions.Explanation: 'Will be launched' matches the future tense.

questions.QuestionText: Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error: 'Traditional practices are ways of knowing, learning and to generate a distinct experience of the world around us.'
questions.OptionD: and to generate a distinct experience
questions.Explanation: 'To generate' should be 'generating' for parallel structure.

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error: 'The teacher asked the class / to be quiet while she / explained the new assignment, / but nobody is listening.'
questions.Explanation: 'Is listening' should be 'was listening' to match past tense.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'In case everybody has left the office, Ashutosh is still busy at his laptop.'
questions.Explanation: 'Even though' better conveys contrast with a conditional.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'The doctor prescribes antibiotics and a cough syrup to me when I had severe cough and cold.'
questions.Explanation: 'Prescribed' aligns with the past tense 'had.'

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error: 'Human activity often / has a negatively effect / on the ecosystem of wetlands.'
questions.Explanation: 'Negatively' should be 'negative' as an adjective.

questions.QuestionText: Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error: 'It is estimating that this forest once covered an area of approximately 400 km.'
questions.Explanation: 'Is estimating' should be 'is estimated' for passive voice.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: 'The author wrote a compelling novel, weaving together multiple storylines that captivated readers until the last page.'
questions.OptionA: A compelling novel was written by the reader, weaving together multiple storylines that captivated the author until the last page.
questions.OptionB: A compelling novel was written by the author, weaving together multiple storylines that captivated readers until the last page.
questions.OptionC: A compelling novel has been written by the author, weaving together multiple storylines that captivated readers until the last page.
questions.OptionD: A compelling novel was writing the author, weaving together multiple storylines that captivated readers until the last page.
questions.Explanation: 'Was written' matches past tense with correct subject.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice: 'Let a statement addressing the recent controversy be issued by the company.'
questions.OptionA: Let the company issue a statement addressing the recent controversy.
questions.OptionB: The company is issuing a statement addressing the recent controversy.
questions.OptionC: The company should issue a statement addressing the recent controversy.
questions.OptionD: The company can issue a statement addressing the recent controversy.
questions.Explanation: 'Let the company issue' retains the imperative form.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: 'Mother asked Rubani if she was sorry for what she had done.'
questions.OptionA: Mother said to Rubani, 'Are you sorry for what she did?'
questions.OptionB: Mother said to Rubani, 'Were you sorry for what you have done?'
questions.OptionC: Mother said to Rubani, 'Do you feel sorry for what you are doing?'
questions.OptionD: Mother said to Rubani, 'Are you sorry for what you have done?'
questions.Explanation: 'Are you sorry' and 'have done' match the indirect form.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blanks: '___ team of two girls succeeded in reaching ___ top of K2, the second highest mountain in the world.'
questions.Explanation: 'A' for an unspecified team; 'the' for the specific top of K2.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'Since last evening, the boy has been complaining with pain in his legs.'
questions.Explanation: 'Complaining of' is the correct phrase.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: 'The little girl said to her friend, "I have brought a chocolate for you."'
questions.OptionA: The little girl told her friend that she had brought a chocolate for her.
questions.OptionB: The little girl told her friend that she has brought a chocolate for you.
questions.OptionC: The little girl told her friend that I had brought a chocolate for her.
questions.OptionD: The little girl told her friend that I have brought a chocolate for you.
questions.Explanation: 'Had brought' and 'her' adjust tense and pronoun correctly.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: 'The courier gave my parcel to my neighbour in my absence.'
questions.OptionA: My neighbour was given to my parcel by the courier in my absence.
questions.OptionB: My parcel was given to my neighbour by the courier in my absence.
questions.OptionC: My parcel had been given to my neighbour by the courier in my absence.
questions.OptionD: My parcel needs to be given to my neighbour by the courier in my absence.
questions.Explanation: 'Was given' matches the past tense action.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'She is allergic from peanuts so she always checks food labels carefully.'
questions.Explanation: 'Allergic to' is the correct preposition.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in direct speech: 'The teacher asked the students which lines of the poem they had not understood.'
questions.OptionA: The teacher said to the students, 'Which lines of the poem you have not understood?'
questions.OptionB: The teacher said to the students, 'Which lines of the poem have they not understood?'
questions.OptionC: The teacher said to the students, 'Which lines of the poem they had not understood?'
questions.OptionD: The teacher said to the students, 'Which lines of the poem had you not understood?'
questions.Explanation: 'Had you not understood' matches the indirect form.

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error: 'You may discussing / your problem / in tomorrow’s meeting.'
questions.Explanation: 'May discussing' should be 'may discuss' (base form after modal).

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'Traffic is always remaining heavy in this part of Delhi.'
questions.Explanation: 'Always remains' corrects to simple present tense.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'Each of the students were asked to submit the project by the following day.'
questions.OptionB: Each of the student was asked
questions.OptionC: Every of the students was asked
questions.OptionD: Each of the students was asked
questions.Explanation: 'Was' agrees with singular 'Each.'

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in indirect speech: 'Avika said to her father, "I have to stay back at school for dance practice today."'
questions.OptionA: Avika told her father that she has to stay back at school for dance practice today.
questions.OptionB: Avika told her father that I have to stay back at school for dance practice today.
questions.OptionC: Avika told her father that she had to stay back at school for dance practice that day.
questions.OptionD: Avika told her father that she will have to stay back at school for dance practice that day.
questions.Explanation: 'Had to' and 'that day' adjust tense and time.

questions.QuestionText: Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error: 'The Board of Directors held a meeting sorting out the issue of the NPAs of the bank.'
questions.Explanation: 'Sorting out' should be 'to sort out' for proper infinitive purpose.

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error: 'Akasa Air planning to acquire / 150 Boeing 737 planes in order to / expand the airline’s reach in / both domestic and international operations.'
questions.Explanation: 'Planning' should be 'is planning' for subject-verb agreement.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice: 'My grandmother called me to the worship place.'
questions.OptionA: I called my grandmother to the worship place.
questions.OptionB: I was called by my grandmother to the worship place.
questions.OptionC: The worship place was called by me to the grandmother.
questions.OptionD: The grandmother was called by me to the worship place.
questions.Explanation: 'Was called' correctly shifts to passive voice.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice: 'The dinner will have been prepared by my sisters.'
questions.OptionA: My sisters will prepare the dinner.
questions.OptionB: My sisters will be preparing the dinner.
questions.OptionC: My sisters will have prepared the dinner.
questions.OptionD: The dinner will have prepared my sisters.
questions.Explanation: 'Will have prepared' matches the future perfect tense.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'The movie was not only interesting but also it was very suspenseful.'
questions.OptionA: but also it is very suspenseful
questions.Explanation: 'But also very suspenseful' maintains parallel structure.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blanks: 'He gave ___ the gift before ___ left for the airport.'
questions.Explanation: 'Her' as object; 'she' as subject of the clause.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence: 'Shimla is the more beautiful hill station in Himachal Pradesh.'
questions.Explanation: 'A very beautiful' corrects the comparative error.

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error: 'A ground-breaking discovery has been made / in a deserting quarry near New York, / where researchers have unearthed / the planet’s most ancient forest.'
questions.OptionB: A ground-breaking discovery has been made
questions.OptionD: in a deserting quarry near New York
questions.Explanation: 'Deserting' should be 'deserted' (abandoned quarry).

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error: 'People under eighteen / do not have / the right to vote, / don’t they?'
questions.Explanation: Tag question should be 'do they?' to match negative statement.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank: 'Anna decided to embark on a challenging journey to learn Mandarin, hoping ___ the language fluently within a year.'
questions.Explanation: 'To speak' is the correct infinitive form after 'hoping.'

questions.QuestionText: The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error: 'Kavya finishes / her homework / before having dinner.'
questions.Explanation: The sentence is grammatically correct.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that expresses the given sentence in reported speech: '"Please listen carefully to what I am teaching," said Madam Mahima to the students.'
questions.OptionA: Madam Mahima requested the students to listen carefully to what she has been teaching.
questions.OptionB: Madam Mahima asked the students to listen carefully to what she is teaching.
questions.OptionC: Madam Mahima said to the students please listen carefully to what I am teaching.
questions.OptionD: Madam Mahima told the students to listen carefully to what she was teaching.
questions.Explanation: 'Told' and 'was teaching' adjust the command and tense.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word: 'Extravagant'
questions.Explanation: 'Restrained' means controlled, opposite to 'extravagant' (wasteful).

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom: 'Be on the same page'
questions.Explanation: Means agreeing or understanding similarly.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: 'Frigid'
questions.Explanation: 'Freezing' means very cold, synonymous with 'frigid.'

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to complete the given idiom: 'Sitting on the ___'
questions.Explanation: 'Sitting on the fence' means being undecided.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom: 'To get someone’s goat'
questions.Explanation: Means to annoy or irritate.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'Lasting for a very short while'
questions.Explanation: 'Ephemeral' means short-lived.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: 'Munificence'
questions.Explanation: 'Munificence' means generosity.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom: 'Be in apple-pie order'
questions.Explanation: Means very neat and organized.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank and complete the given idiom: 'Bite the ___'
questions.Explanation: 'Bite the bullet' means to face a difficult situation bravely.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank and complete the given idiom: 'Piece of ___'
questions.Explanation: 'Piece of cake' means something easy.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word: 'Mitigate'
questions.Explanation: 'Intensify' means to increase, opposite of 'mitigate' (reduce).

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'Protect from a danger, risk, or unpleasant experience'
questions.Explanation: 'Shield' means to protect.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'An eloquent and skilled public speaker'
questions.Explanation: 'Orator' refers to a skilled speaker.

questions.QuestionText: Select the INCORRECTLY spelt word:
questions.Explanation: 'Irrelevant' seems intended to be misspelled in context, though all are correct here; assume typo in original.

questions.QuestionText: Select the INCORRECTLY spelt word:
questions.Explanation: 'Hungery' should be 'Hungry.'

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to complete the given idiom: 'Spill the ___'
questions.Explanation: 'Spill the beans' means to reveal a secret.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: 'Devour'
questions.Explanation: 'Consume' means to eat or use up, like 'devour.'

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'The person who presents and coordinates a show on stage or television'
questions.Explanation: 'Anchor' fits a presenter role.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: 'Genesis'
questions.Explanation: 'Inception' means beginning, like 'genesis.'

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: 'Feasible'
questions.Explanation: 'Practical' means possible, like 'feasible.'

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'Not able to be changed or adapted'
questions.Explanation: 'Rigid' means inflexible.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word: 'Oaf'
questions.Explanation: 'Smart' is opposite to 'oaf' (foolish person).

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom: 'Cut from the same cloth'
questions.OptionC: To belong to the same family
questions.Explanation: Means having similar characteristics.

questions.QuestionText: Select the INCORRECTLY spelt word:
questions.Explanation: Assume typo in original; 'Observe' intended as misspelling.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'Not active but has the ability to be active anytime later'
questions.Explanation: 'Dormant' means inactive but capable of activity.

questions.QuestionText: Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the given group of words: 'A complete, usually alphabetical list of items, often with notes giving details.'
questions.Explanation: 'Catalogue' fits a detailed list.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate meaning of the given idiom: 'Split one’s sides'
questions.Explanation: Means to laugh very hard.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank and complete the given idiom: 'Hit the ___'
questions.Explanation: 'Hit the sack' means to go to bed.

questions.QuestionText: Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word: 'Exuberance'
questions.Explanation: 'Excitement' matches 'exuberance' (high energy).

questions.QuestionText:
Given below are six sentences of a paragraph. Sentence A is the beginning whereas sentence F is the last sentence of the para. The middle four sentences (B-E) are jumbled up. Select the option that gives their correct order forming a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. A youngster quit Facebook in December after spending over three years on the social networking site.
B. Like almost everyone from his 'friend’s circle,' the 20-year-old was a regular on the site.
C. Last week a new feature on Facebook called Timeline forced him to reconsider the pros and cons of being on the networking site.
D. With that one act, he bid a silent adieu to more than 300 contacts that he had added to his account during the period.
E. He visited it every day to post photos and status updates.
F. 'Everyone has some skeletons in their closet and I am just not comfortable with Facebook digging up and displaying all the facets of my life on a bulletin board,' said the youngster.
questions.Explanation: DBEC flows logically: quitting (D), regular use (B), daily activity (E), new feature prompting reconsideration (C).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. There are about eighty houses in the village, which is the seat of two district governors who administer thirty villages.
B. We were told that we were the first Europeans who had ever come to Kyirong, and the inhabitants watched our entry with astonishment.
C. This time we were quartered in the house of a farmer, which reminded me of our Tyrolese houses.
D. The only difference was that instead of chimneys, the roofs of the houses were decorated with prayer flags.
E. As a matter of fact, the whole of the village might have been transplanted from the Alps.
F. These were always in the five colours, which represented different aspects of life in Tibet.
questions.Explanation: BCED: arrival (B), housing (C), similarity to Alps (E), difference in roofs (D).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. 'I’ll forget it for sure,' said the Hodja, 'Write it on a piece of paper for me.'
B. Hodja Nasruddin purchased a piece of meat at the market, and on his way home he met a friend.
C. The friend wrote, 'Don’t forget the meat,' and handed the note to Hodja.
D. When he got home, he took out the note and read it aloud to his wife.
E. His wife asked, 'Where is the meat?' and Hodja replied, 'Oh no! I forgot it after all.'
questions.Explanation: BACDE: Hodja buys meat and meets friend (B), expresses forgetfulness (A), friend writes note (C), reads note at home (D), realizes he forgot (E).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. Scientists have long been intrigued by the concept of time travel.
B. Some argue that wormholes—hypothetical tunnels through spacetime—could make it feasible.
C. However, no concrete evidence has yet been found to support these theories in practice.
D. Theoretical physics offers several possibilities, including Einstein’s theory of relativity.
E. Despite the fascination, time travel remains a speculative idea rather than a proven phenomenon.
F. Until technology advances significantly, it will stay confined to the realm of science fiction.
questions.Explanation: DBEC: Theoretical basis (D), wormhole possibility (B), lack of evidence (E), speculative nature (C).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. She decided to plant a small garden in her backyard.
B. Every morning, she watered the plants and checked their progress.
C. Within a few weeks, tiny green shoots began to appear.
D. By the end of summer, her garden was full of colorful flowers and fresh vegetables.
E. She chose a variety of seeds, including tomatoes, carrots, and marigolds.
questions.Explanation: AECBD: Decision to plant (A), seed selection (E), watering routine (B), shoots appear (C), full garden (D).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The annual village fair was a much-awaited event for everyone.
B. Children ran around excitedly, playing games and enjoying rides.
C. By evening, the fairground was illuminated with colorful lights.
D. Local artisans displayed their crafts, attracting many visitors.
E. The day ended with a spectacular fireworks display that left everyone in awe.
F. It was a celebration that brought the entire community together.
questions.Explanation: DBCE: Crafts displayed (D), children’s activities (B), evening lights (C), fireworks (E).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. He packed his bags and headed to the station early in the morning.
B. The train journey offered stunning views of the countryside.
C. After months of planning, Rohan finally set off on his solo trip.
D. He arrived at his destination by noon and checked into a small guesthouse.
E. Along the way, he made notes of interesting places to explore.
questions.Explanation: CBAED: Planning (C), packing (A), train views (B), notes (E), arrival (D).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The discovery of penicillin marked a turning point in medical history.
B. This breakthrough drastically reduced mortality rates from bacterial infections.
C. It was accidentally found by Alexander Fleming in 1928 when he noticed mold inhibiting bacterial growth.
D. Over the years, penicillin paved the way for the development of other antibiotics.
E. Initially, its potential was not fully recognized until further research in the 1940s.
F. Today, it remains one of the most significant contributions to modern medicine.
questions.Explanation: CDEB: Discovery (C), initial oversight (E), impact (D), reduced mortality (B).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The storm hit the coastal town with unexpected ferocity.
B. By morning, the streets were flooded, and power lines were down.
C. Residents had been warned earlier, but few anticipated its strength.
D. Emergency services worked tirelessly to rescue stranded families.
E. Over the next few days, the community came together to rebuild.
questions.Explanation: ACBDE: Storm hits (A), warning ignored (C), flooding (B), rescue (D), rebuilding (E).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. Learning a new language can be a rewarding experience.
B. It also opens doors to new career opportunities and cultural understanding.
C. Regular practice is essential to build vocabulary and improve fluency.
D. Initially, it requires patience as mastering grammar and pronunciation takes time.
E. Over time, learners often find themselves thinking in the new language.
F. Ultimately, the effort pays off with the ability to communicate effectively.
questions.Explanation: DCEB: Initial effort (D), practice (C), thinking in language (E), opportunities (B).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. She enrolled in an online course to enhance her skills.
B. After completing it, she applied for a promotion at work.
C. The course required her to dedicate several hours each week.
D. Her hard work paid off when she was selected for the new role.
E. Initially, she struggled to balance her job and studies.
questions.Explanation: AECBD: Enrollment (A), struggle (E), dedication (C), completion (B), promotion (D).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The invention of the printing press revolutionized the spread of knowledge.
B. Books became more accessible, leading to increased literacy rates.
C. Johannes Gutenberg developed this technology in the mid-15th century.
D. Before this, manuscripts were laboriously copied by hand.
E. The impact was profound, as ideas could now reach a wider audience quickly.
F. It laid the foundation for the modern era of mass communication.
questions.Explanation: CDBE: Gutenberg’s invention (C), previous method (D), accessibility (B), impact (E).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. He spent hours researching the best techniques for baking.
B. His friends praised the delicious cake he made for the party.
C. Determined to impress, he decided to bake a cake from scratch.
D. After several failed attempts, he finally perfected the recipe.
E. The process taught him patience and attention to detail.
questions.Explanation: CADEB: Decision (C), research (A), failures (D), perfection (E), praise (B).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The migration of birds is a fascinating natural phenomenon.
B. Many species travel thousands of miles to reach their breeding grounds.
C. They rely on environmental cues like temperature and daylight to time their journeys.
D. Along the way, they face challenges such as predators and exhaustion.
E. Scientists study these patterns to understand climate change impacts.
F. Their incredible journeys highlight the wonders of the animal kingdom.
questions.Explanation: CBDE: Cues (C), travel distance (B), challenges (D), scientific study (E).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The library was quiet except for the sound of turning pages.
B. She found a cozy corner and settled in with her book.
C. By afternoon, she had finished reading an entire novel.
D. She visited the library every weekend to escape into stories.
E. The smell of old books filled the air as she browsed the shelves.
questions.Explanation: DAEBC: Habit (D), library atmosphere (A), browsing (E), settling (B), finishing (C).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below. While the first and the last sentences (A and F) are in the correct order, the sentences in between are jumbled up. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. Solar energy is becoming an increasingly popular renewable resource.
B. Advances in technology have made solar panels more efficient and affordable.
C. Governments worldwide are offering incentives to encourage its adoption.
D. It reduces reliance on fossil fuels, helping combat climate change.
E. As a result, more households and businesses are switching to solar power.
F. Its widespread use could transform the global energy landscape.
questions.Explanation: BCDE: Technology (B), incentives (C), environmental benefit (D), adoption (E).

questions.QuestionText:
Sentences of a paragraph are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the sentences in the correct order to form a meaningful and coherent paragraph.
A. The festival began with a vibrant parade through the town.
B. Local musicians played traditional tunes, adding to the festive mood.
C. Visitors enjoyed a variety of foods from street vendors.
D. By nightfall, the sky lit up with a dazzling fireworks display.
E. People gathered early to secure spots along the main street.
questions.Explanation: EABCD: Gathering (E), parade (A), music (B), food (C), fireworks (D).
